Award.AwardTitle: Digitization TCN: Collaborative Research: The Cretaceous World: Digitizing Fossils to Reconstruct Evolving Ecosystems in the Western Interior Seaway
Award.AbstractNarration:
Between 65 and 100 million years ago, during the time that dinosaurs walked the earth, a large, tropical seaway covered the central part of what is now North America. This seaway teemed with marine life. Snails and clams lived on the seafloor; ammonites, along with giant mosasaurs, plesiosaurs, sharks, and fish, swam about; at the same time early birds and pterosaurs floated on or flew above the seaway. What remains today is a prolific fossil record that has been collected by paleontologists for over 100 years. Notable fossils from this time period and region are on display at museums around the world. However, the vast bulk of fossils collected from this region are locked away in museum drawers. To provide scientists and the general public access to these fossils and their associated data, this project proposes to digitize invertebrate and vertebrate fossils from this time period and region, making information accessible through searchable electronic databases. Additionally, a variety of online resources illustrating and describing these fossils and mapping their distributions will be developed. A freely accessible online textbook of paleontology will be generated and a website and App will be developed to highlight the appearances, occurrences, and ages of constituent species, to help students and aspiring paleontologists identify and learn about these fossils. The project plans to generate a variety of curricular materials for K-12 education, including 3-D scans of fossils for free download and printed 3-D models for classroom use. Products of this project will also include workshops to engage science teachers and items to augment public programs and exhibits at participating institutions.

This work will greatly increase the scientific value of eight major U.S. museum collections of fossils. The museum collections contain large amounts of data useful for studying what causes marine species to migrate, go extinct, and evolve during a long period of greenhouse climate conditions similar to those our planet may soon experience. These data have relevance for evaluating how global change has and will continue to affect life on earth. An estimated 164,000 specimens collected from thousands of locations, in the region once occupied by the Western Interior Seaway, will be databased and georeferenced. Representatives from each of roughly 1,500 microfossil, invertebrate, and vertebrate species will be imaged. The digitized records will be made available online via individual museum databases, iDigBio, and iDigPaleo. The resultant data will enable scientists to answer questions about how different species interact and ecosystems change in the face of environmental shifts during a key time in the history of life. Moreover, the data will be ideal for use with an assortment of modern quantitative tools -including paleoecological niche modeling (PaleoENM) - and will help improve paleoclimate and paleoceanographic models. Finally, several undergraduate and graduate students will be trained. Results of the project will be published at the following url: www.digitalatlasofancientlife.org.

Institution.Name: Paleontological Research Institute
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: MUSEUM OF THE EARTH AT THE PALEONTOLOGICAL RESEARCH INSTITUTION

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
The most significant goal of the Paleontological Research Institution portion of the Cretaceous World Thematic Collections Network (TCN) project was to expand the existing Digital Atlas of Ancient Life project (https://www.digitalatlasofancientlife.org/), which is devoted to helping students, their teachers, and the wider public identify fossils and learn about ancient life. This was done through the development of three new online resources: the Cretaceous Atlas of Ancient Life, the Digital Encyclopedia of Ancient Life, and the Digital Atlas Virtual Collection.

The Cretaceous Atlas of Ancient Life (https://www.cretaceousatlas.org/) is an online field guide to ancient species that inhabited a shallow seaway that flooded the North American midcontinent during the Late Cretaceous Period (from about 100 to 66 million years ago) and left behind a rich fossil record of invertebrates like clams, snails, and ammonites, as well as vertebrates such as fish, mosasaurs, and plesiosaurs (see geological overview at https://www.cretaceousatlas.org/geology/). The Cretaceous Atlas provides tools to help the public identify specimens from this rich fossil record. Over 760 species are featured on the Cretaceous Atlas. Photographs of each species are provided, as well as information about their taxonomy, geological range, geographic distribution, and stratigraphic occurrences. Distributional maps are also available for many species. 

The Digital Encyclopedia of Ancient Life (https://www.digitalatlasofancientlife.org/learn/) is a free, open access, online textbook about paleontology and the fossil record designed for college students (or advanced high school students) who are taking their first introductory course in paleontology or historical geology. Conceptual chapters cover the following topics: nature of the fossil record, geological time, evolution and the fossil record, systematics, paleoecology, conservation paleobiology, and animal phylogeny. The remaining chapters are focused on different taxonomic groups and currently include coverage of sponges (Porifera), corals, brachiopods, bryozoans, mollusks, echinoderms, jawless vertebrates, and some groups of land plants. A chapter on arthropods is in development. A user-guide chapter about photogrammetry (the method used to create the 3D models described below) is also available.

A final major component that was added to the Digital Atlas as part of this National Science Foundation-supported project was the development of a Virtual Collection (https://www.digitalatlasofancientlife.org/vc/) of over 500 interactive 3D photogrammetry models of fossil specimens from the collections and exhibits of the Paleontological Research Institution and its Museum of the Earth. These 3D models have been curated into taxonomically arranged online collections, akin to the drawers of physical specimens that an instructor might share during a laboratory exercise. The models have also been incorporated throughout the Digital Encyclopedia of Ancient Life. Almost all of the models, which are hosted on the Sketchfab website, have been given Creative Commons 0 public domain licensing, allowing members of the public to use them however they wish (for example, all may be freely downloaded and 3D printed). This collection of 3D models proved especially useful to college instructors during the COVID-19 pandemic when in-person teaching that involved observation of actual fossil specimens shifted quickly to an online format. 

The resources described above have been utilized by many thousands of individuals from around the United States and world, and have been presented at numerous professional conferences and also workshops for educators.


Last Modified: 10/29/2020
Modified by: Jonathan Hendricks
